Expectation1: Communicate politely and professionally with customers
Situation1: The customer asks about the delivery status, while a delivery issue arises, such as a delayed or misplaced package
Expectation2: Organize and participate in peaceful protests to raise awareness about social issues.
Situation2: Police have just begun to unexpectedly block the exits of the protest area, and you must immediately help coordinate a safe response.
Story: My phone buzzed as I balanced a stack of packages outside a customer’s door. I answered, putting on my best professional tone. “Hello, this is your delivery driver. I’m so sorry, but there’s been a delay with your package—” The customer’s frustration was immediate, and I tried to reassure them, even as my other phone vibrated urgently in my pocket. I glanced at the screen: messages from my activist group, panic in every word. The police had started blocking the exits at our protest downtown, and I was supposed to help coordinate a safe response, making sure everyone stayed calm and found a way out. My heart pounded. The customer demanded answers, expecting patience and professionalism. My friends at the protest needed me to act fast, to be decisive and brave. I felt split in two, the weight of both roles pressing down on me, each demanding my full attention, each with consequences if I failed. I stood there, torn, the world waiting for me to choose.
